prompt:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
For API StringTokenizer.nextToken, the API usage rule is: Create a StringTokenizer with a specified string and delimiter, and then obtain the next token as long as there are more tokens available.

Question: file manipulation using tokenizer: :import java.io.*;import java.util.Scanner;import java.util.StringTokenizer;public class Filereader {    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {File fil = new File("trans1.txt");FileReader inputFil = new FileReader(fil);BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(inputFil);//Create scanner to read contents of a fileScanner scanner = new Scanner(new File("trans1.txt"));//Create an array to store contents of a file after reading themString [] tall = new String [100];int i = 0;while(scanner.hasNext()){//Create StringTokenizer object   StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(scanner.next(),"< , { } >", true);   tall[i] = scanner.next();   System.out.println(tall[i]);   i++;  }    in.close();  } }I want to read contents of a file into an array using the code above and print the values stored in the array to screen. Each time i run the code i dont get the desired output,can someone please help. Contents of my file are as follows;5 <0,{p1}><0,{p1}>  -1-> <1><1,{p1}>  -2-> <2><3><2,{p0}>  -1-> <0><3,{p1}>  -1-> <4><4,{p0}>  -1-> <3>
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer:
response:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>:
import java.io.*;
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

public class Filereader {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        File fil = new File("trans1.txt");
        FileReader inputFil = new FileReader(fil);
        BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(inputFil);

        // Create scanner to read contents of a file
        Scanner scanner = new Scanner(new File("trans1.txt"));

        // Create an array to store contents of a file after reading them
        String[] tall = new String[100];
        int i = 0;

        while (scanner.hasNext()) {
            // Create StringTokenizer object
            StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(scanner.next(), "< , { } >", true);
            tall[i] = st.nextToken(); // Use StringTokenizer.nextToken to get the next token
            System.out.println(tall[i]);
            i++;
        }

        in.close();
    }
}

<<<explanation>>>: In the given code, you are trying to read the contents of a file into an array using the Scanner class. However, you are not using the StringTokenizer correctly to extract the tokens from each line of the file.

To fix this, you need to create a StringTokenizer object and use its nextToken() method to get the next token from the line. In your code, you are directly assigning the next token to the array without using the StringTokenizer.

I have modified your code to use the StringTokenizer correctly. Now, it will read each line from the file, tokenize it using the specified delimiters ("< , { } >"), and store the tokens in the array. The tokens will then be printed to the screen.

Note: Make sure the file "trans1.txt" exists in the same directory as your Java file.

message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>:
import java.io.*;
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

public class Filereader {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        File fil = new File("trans1.txt");
        FileReader inputFil = new FileReader(fil);
        BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(inputFil);

        // Create scanner to read contents of a file
        Scanner scanner = new Scanner(new File("trans1.txt"));

        // Create an array to store contents of a file after reading them
        String[] tall = new String[100];
        int i = 0;

        while (scanner.hasNext()) {
            // Create StringTokenizer object
            StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(scanner.next(), "< , { } >", true);
            tall[i] = st.nextToken(); // Use StringTokenizer.nextToken to get the next token
            System.out.println(tall[i]);
            i++;
        }

        in.close();
    }
}

<<<explanation>>>: In the given code, you are trying to read the contents of a file into an array using the Scanner class. However, you are not using the StringTokenizer correctly to extract the tokens from each line of the file.

To fix this, you need to create a StringTokenizer object and use its nextToken() method to get the next token from the line. In your code, you are directly assigning the next token to the array without using the StringTokenizer.

I have modified your code to use the StringTokenizer correctly. Now, it will read each line from the file, tokenize it using the specified delimiters ("< , { } >"), and store the tokens in the array. The tokens will then be printed to the screen.

Note: Make sure the file "trans1.txt" exists in the same directory as your Java file.
